html:
Etymology[edit]

From laxus (“loose, open”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈlak.soː/, [ˈɫ̪ak.soː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈlak.so/, [ˈlak.sɔ]

Verb[edit]

laxō (present infinitive laxāre, perfect active laxāvī, supine laxātum); first conjugation

  1. I extend, expand
  2. I open, make wide
  3. I undo, release
  4. (figuratively) I lighten, relieve, free
  5. I relax, moderate, weaken
  6. I lessen, abate

Derived terms[edit]

  • laxāmentum
  • laxātiō
  • laxātīvus
  • relaxō
 

Related terms[edit]

  • laxātus
  • laxē
  • laxitās
  • laxus
 

Descendants[edit]

  • Aragonese: deixar
  • Aromanian: alas, las, alãsari, lãsari
  • Catalan: deixar
  • Corsican: lascià
  • Friulian: lassâ
  • Istriot: lassà
  • Italian: lasciare, lassare
  • Ladin: lascer
  • Leonese: deixare
    • Asturian: dexar, llexar
  • Neapolitan: lassà, lascià
  • Occitan: daissar, laissar
  • Old French: lessier, laissier, laschier
    • French: laisser, lâcher; ⇒ délaisser
    • Jersey Norman: laîssi
    • Walloon: låtchî
  • Old Portuguese: leixar
    • Galician: deixar
    • Portuguese: deixar
  • Old Spanish: lexar, dexar
    • Spanish: dejar
  • Picard: laissier
  • Piedmontese: lassé
  • → Portuguese: laxar
  • Romanian: lăsa, lăsare
  • Romansch: laschar, lascher, schar
  • Sardinian: lassai, lassare, dassare
  • Sicilian: lassari, dassari
  • → Spanish: laxar
  • Venetian: lasar
  • → Albanian: lëshoj

References[edit]

  • laxo in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • laxo in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • laxo in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  • Carl Meissner; Henry William Auden (1894) Latin Phrase-Book‎[1], London: Macmillan and Co.
    • the price of corn is going down: annona laxatur, levatur, vilior fit
    • (ambiguous) to fight in open order: laxatis (opp. confertis) ordinibus pugnare
